pros: they're in fewer countries now than ever before?
cons: where to start? sclerotic policies. management totally disconnected with and wholly uninterested in ground realities. non existent lines of communication, only top down diktat. middle management of kowtowing men and women trying to make the point that they are equal to the task all the while struggling to muddle through to the next paycheck. An example of how ludicrous things are here. the branding/communications/marketing function/leadership three years ago have default set everyone's internal email to 9 point Arial black. zero tolerance /harsh put down for anyone asking to understand why. management that revels in a new set of acronyms/jargon developed almost fortnightly with these latest mantras sung like portents of the new age. a new Babylon built late into every night with work to begin from scratch on a new Babylon with the next dawn. and yet for all that hard slough each day not an inch of progress/value add. absolutely no tolerance for nor any forum made available to put up a differing opinion let alone a query on the latest vibe/slough. a human 'resource' function willingly party to all manner of discrimination, micro aggressions, privilege and abuse. any 'concern' is supposedly a 'grievance' the management process of which puts the 'whiner' up front and center, with the burden of proof to provide. the 'resolution' process of any 'grievance'  is administered by and provides cover to the very people who are supposed to not be complicit in the perpetuation of these same wrongs. moot point thus to point out any wrong. not many have the guts to put up their hand let alone to stand up in this system anymore for those that have previously had such temerity were made examples of with stagnating careers, bad reviews, management opprobrium, and exclusion from any opportunity. that is if they stuck around long enough through the tarring. the bare minimum of mediocrity coupled with excellence at schmoozing is guaranteed to see one's career grow. that and one's passport/skin color/ethnicity. everyone else is told to do more, that their growth is up to them. when they hire its mostly in jurisdictions that have discriminatory /locals only bar (which they never disclose when advertising roles). the great majority of any open positions as is are always filled with 'outsiders'. such demonstrable faith they have in the capabilities and capacity of their existing staff to deliver. the organization pays out the most in locations where it does little business, head quartered and top heavy staffed in the UK where although it has never had a retail presence, its paid annually through the nose to the FSA purportedly for deposit protection? add to the redundant upper management structure replicated across 'regions' - very well paid upper management. save pennies to spend pounds they have always been with massive cost pressures put on lower staff cadres /hiring/ reward while the bloat keeps increasing in the upper echelons. management aspires and compares itself to the big banks, goldman sachs, jp morgan et all, remaining obliviate to the differences in business model, staff benefits/ quality, hiring competence/ training standards and internal policies. while all countries are expected to comply with increasingly vague jargon filled indeterminate internal policies as they see fit to interpret them, there are vastly differing standards for anything remotely related to staff/hr are concerned. there are vastly differing standards for policies on pay and protection for human resources for the same role, between different countries and even within a country to the extent that locals are paid far more and much better for the 'same' work on paper as non locals no matter the performance delivery hours etc. diversity and inclusion are 'big' here. oft touted. but its never about equity and always only means' we will hire more women'. the active gender discrimination isn't overt, they actually say so. not that many women have been hired but the mantra has been used effectively to not provide opportunity to grow to existing staff. the archaic attitudes don't change, but the positive discrimination provides entitlement to all sorts of mediocrity and discrimination is rife here. all this has increasingly created  a very toxic unhealthy work environment here with the inequities that just keep piling up.

pros: I had an amazing job at SCB and worked with great people.
cons:
The workload is overwhelming and you are not given the resources to do your job. Pay is far below average and raises are very far between. There is a lot of consolidation of jobs, so you will be forced to do multiple roles without any additional support or compensation. This makes it interesting because you gain a lot of experience, but also there is no work life balance. It’s all work.

Promotions are difficult to receive. Many years in a row there were no promotions.

 The majority of the women in senior roles left the bank in 2021. They all left within a few months of each other. This speaks to the rampant sexism present at SCB. Mediocre males are promoted above talented women time and time again.

review_title: Great Bank but choose your Line Manager wisely
pros:
- Innovative Bank that strives to keep up with the technology
- Leaders try to foster a good working culture (i.e. a Bank that cares)
- flexible working and nice benefits
- volunteer opportunities
cons:
The bank may care but be aware that implementations of all Bank policies is left to the Line Managers’ discretion . 
If you have a bad manager, she / he can make life hell (e.g very political environment, no increment for successive years, refusal to keep up with times especially on flexible working etc) and there will be zero support .  
Unfortunately there is no review process for the effectiveness of a line manager (apart from the yearly employee assessment which brings no results).

As with all careers,  choose your line manager wisely as your career in the Bank is dependent on that!
